learning_outcomes.description: Formulate a computational problem from a design scenario and apply appropriate computational techniques.
Undertake analysis and design of complex structural forms by considered application of computational methods.
Evaluate the limitations of computational methods in structural and building design.
Manage personal independent learning through use of resources to develop capacity in various softwares (e.g. online software tutorials, forums, etc).
Apply model interoperability and collaborative digital workflow development with group work.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 1 - Component Design and Development Report
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

There are two parts of Assessment 1 - Component Design and Development. 

Part 1 - Formative

Submission of 3 Software Training Modules Certificates. Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

Part 2 - Summative 30%

This assignment submission will require students to demonstrate their understanding of the parametric modelling, generative modelling, and interoperable digital workflows as introduced in the first half of the course. The assignment will be an individual submission uploaded to Blackboard, with the submission to include a computational model and a short accompanying report. Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessment must be submitted through the course BlackBoard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2 - Research Framework and Workflow Report
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2 - Research framework and workflow is an interim submission leading to the final research project for the course.

This Assessment will comprise one submission uploaded to Blackboard:

Part 1 - Formative

Completion of 1 Software Training Module. Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

Part 2 - Summative 20%

An individual assessment component (20% weighting), including a research report. In this report, students should identify the background, aim, challenges, workflow, and framework for a final research project.

Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

Assessment Rationale: 

Assessment 2 - Research framework and workflow is an interim submission leading to the final research project for the course. 

An individual assessment component, including a research report. In this report, students should identify the background, aim, challenges, workflow, and framework for a final research project. Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessment must be submitted through the course BlackBoard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 3 - Major Research Project (IVAH, Group and Individual)
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

This final project is the major assessment item for the course. The project will comprise two submissions, both to be uploaded to Blackboard.

Part 1 - Summative 30%

An individual assessment component, including a highly resolved computational model and accompanying research report.

Part 2 - Summative 20%

A group assessment component, including a final computational model that integrates individual models from each group member; and a (pre-recorded) group presentation that demonstrates model design and operation. Anonymous peer assessment will be applied to monitor group work and weight the marks. Further specific Assessment details will be made available via Blackboard.

If, for whatever reason, you find that your group is not functioning effectively, please contact your Course Coordinator for support.

NOTE: This assessment is Identity verified assessment with a hurdle (IVAH)

In order to pass this course students must achieve a minimum grade of 3 for the IVAH designated assessment item(s).

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessment must be submitted through the course BlackBoard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
To pass this course, all students must participate in the timetabled IT Workshop sessions. Note the emphasis on participation - it is not sufficient just to attend.

Workshop attendance and participation will be formally monitored from Weeks 6 to 13, with students and project teams required to meet weekly with course staff (academics or tutors) to provide a brief verbal report of progress made toward the major research project (including Assessment 2 intermim submission and Assessment 3 final submission). Participation in these weekly meetings is recorded by your tutor/mentor.

If you are unable to attend any session, contact the course coordinator as soon as is possible. In special cases, permission may be granted for students to attend fewer sessions. Such permission will not be granted unless exceptional personal circumstances prevent attendance (e.g. documented medical reason or family emergency).

The course staff may also request information to evidence student project work completion, so students are expected to keep evidence of their own individual work, including notes, report drafts, and progressive versions of their computational model.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Meet with course staff during the weekly workshop sessions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(28 Jul - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Week 1 - Parametric Design : Couse outline, computational design overview, parametric modelling, model development, and design. terminology, and operation of computation design.

Week 2 - Parametric Design : Couse outline, computational design overview, parametric modelling, model development, and design. terminology, and operation of computation design.

Week 3 - Development of digital workflows for larger and more complex systems and design problems.

Week 4 - Extended methods for geometric modelling - generative assembly and subdivision.

Week 5 - Extended methods for geometric modelling - generative assembly and subdivision.

Week 6 - Development of digital workflows for larger and more complex systems and design problems.

Week 7 - Performance Analysis, Responsiveness, Optimisation, and Form-Finding

Week 8 - Performance Analysis, Responsiveness, Optimisation, and Form-Finding

Week 9 - Performance Analysis, Responsiveness, Optimisation, and Form-Finding

Week 10 - Advanced Manufacturing, Digital Fabrication, Mass Customisation, and Robotic Construction

Week 11 - Advanced Manufacturing, Digital Fabrication, Mass Customisation, and Robotic Construction

Week 12 - Advanced Manufacturing, Digital Fabrication, Mass Customisation, and Robotic Construction

Week 13 -  No lecture


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
IT Labs

Week 1 - 4 - Software labs to introduce various computational design tools and develop capacity in computational methods.

Week 5 - 6 - Workflow design and research development

Week 7 - 12 - Advanced component explorations, final assignment group selection and workflow development
